subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Poll results for Read_Alphabet
msgSnippet: Yes the poll results are hard to interpret.  For example they are ambiguous in at least one way: More people voted for QS keyboard mapping that included the
messageBody:
Yes the poll results are hard to interpret. For
example they are ambiguous in at least one way: More
people voted for QS keyboard mapping that included the
"half" letters than voted for a keyboard mapping that
did not. If (hypothetically of course) one were to
have a two-way "run-off" between Peter Guiness's
proposal and QS-B (or Moira's proposal which resembles
Peter's in many ways but includes the half-letters)
would Peter's still win? But given the extremely low
participation in the poll, i don't know if it would be
worth it to have a run off.
Just my two cents.
BcS

--- Ted Larson Freeman <freeman@...>
wrote:

> I'm not sure how to interpret the results of this
> poll. On the one
> hand, we could declare it a success. Peter
> Guinness's proposal won! We
> now have a standard that font developers can use for
> QS keyboard
> assignments. And we can begin posting messages to
> the group using this
> ASCII mapping. Those were the goals.
>
> On the other hand, the participation rate of less
> than 4% was far
> below my most pessimistic expectation. Can we really
> claim to have a
> standard that was chosen by only six people?
>
> I don't know.
>
> Ted
>
>
> On 1 Mar 2008 08:43:19 -0000,
> <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > The following Read_Alphabet poll is now closed.
> Here are the
> > final results:
> >
> > POLL QUESTION: Please vote for your preference
> for a new ASCII key map for
> > the Read Alphabet, from among the proposals
> included in the file
> > 'qs_keybd_proposals3.csv' in the 'Files->Key
> mapping proposals' folder on
> > the group website.
> >
> > The purpose of this vote is to establish a
> standard for font developers to
> > implement in keyboard assignments, and to
> facilitate the exchange of
> > Quickscript in email and in plain text documents.
> >
> > The scope of the proposals includes the 40 core
> letters of the alphabet,
> > the four alternate letters, the two letters used
> for Scottish, Welsh and
> > Irish place names, and the three punctuation marks
> unique to this alphabet.
> > Some proposals also include the eight
> half-letters. In order to be
> > considered, the proposals were required to assign
> all free-standing
> > Quickscript letters to upper case or lower case
> Roman letters. (There are
> > not enough letters in the Roman alphabet to
> maintain this requirement for
> > all of the half-letters.) Since the Jerome
> keyboard map does not meet this
> > requirement, and proposals for a minimal update of
> the Jerome map gained no
> > support in group discussion, it is not included
> among the final candidates.
> >
> > This poll will close at the end of February 2008.
> >
> > Thank you for voting!
> >
> > Ted Larson Freeman
> >
> >
> > CHOICES AND RESULTS
> > - QS-SAMPA, 0 votes, 0.00%
> > - Peter Guinness's proposal, 6 votes, 46.15%
> > - QS-B, 5 votes, 38.46%
> > - QS-Nu, 0 votes, 0.00%
> > - Moira O'Brien's proposal, 2 votes, 15.38%
> >
> > For more information about this group, please
> visit
> > http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet
> >
> > For help with Yahoo! Groups, please visit
> >
>
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/web/index.html
> >
> >
>

Yes the poll results are hard to interpret.  For
example they are ambiguous in at least one way: More
people voted for QS keyboard mapping that included the
"half" letters than voted for a keyboard mapping that
did not.  If (hypothetically of course) one were to
have a two-way "run-off" between Peter Guiness's
proposal and QS-B (or Moira's proposal which resembles
Peter's in many ways but includes the half-letters)
would Peter's still win?  But given the extremely low
participation in the poll, i don't know if it would be
worth it to have a run off.
Just my two cents.
BcS
